awd_titl_txt: RAPID: STEM faculty support to address impacts from COVID-19 on Tribal Colleges and Universities Program institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education, and sustainability of capacity gains is significantly enhanced by retaining the talent of credentialed STEM faculty.  This project aligns directly with that goal.

The coronavirus pandemic of 2020-2021 caused major disruptions to institutions of higher education.  However, for tribal colleges and universities, whose core operating funds are directly aligned with student enrollment, drops in enrollment equate to loss of funding.  To mitigate against detrimental effects on STEM instructional capacity, this award will support the position of one full-time STEM faculty member, as well as other resources to maintain Keweenaw Bay Ojibway Community College’s STEM program as it recovers from the impact of the pandemic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The impact of this project has been transformative, bringing about positive changes in teaching and learning mathematics at Keweenaw Bay Ojibwa Community College (KBOCC). Through attending instructor training provided by Data and Software Carpentries and the educator Fire Circles, my professional toolkit has expanded with valuable tools and strategies to effectively work with adult learners in remote spaces centering on Indigenous ways of knowing. This training has empowered me to implement formative assessments in an equitable manner, incorporating cultural contextualization, all while considering cognitive load, and integrating complex software coding in R within my teaching practices.

With this newfound expertise, I have modified my approach to teaching math at the tribal college, resulting in improved student outcomes. The incorporation of culturally sustaining and culturally relevant content has fostered a more engaging and meaningful learning experience for our students. The success of these modifications prompted me to share my insights with our faculty council through a workshop module titled "The 4 Directions of Student Engagement: Embracing Indigenous Cultural Relevance in Online Spaces." This module, centered around the four directions of engagement, provides practical guidance on planning and facilitating equitable and culturally sustaining online and hybrid learning environments for students from tribal colleges.

  Furthermore, the project funding allowed our institution to establish a state-of-the-art computational lab, addressing the barriers associated with teaching high-level math courses, including statistics and quantitative reasoning, in synchronous and HyFlex modalities. Equipped with advanced computational tools and software, we are now able to integrate coding in excel and R, enhancing students' analytical and problem-solving skills. This investment has significantly increased access to computational resources, enabling our students to develop proficiency in data analysis and computational thinking, which are essential skills in today's digital age.

The impact of these initiatives is far-reaching. Students at KBOCC are experiencing higher levels of engagement, leading to improved learning outcomes in all  math courses. By embracing culturally sustaining and culturally relevant content, our courses are honoring and respecting the unique cultural backgrounds of our students and our mission as a tribal college, creating an inclusive and empowering educational environment. The success of this instructional approach has also inspired other faculty members at KBOCC, fostering a collaborative community of educators dedicated to enhancing student learning experiences.

This project has had a profound impact on teaching and learning mathematics at KBOCC. Through the implementation of innovative instructional strategies, the creation of a workshop module, and the establishment of a computational lab, we have empowered students and instructors, enhanced access to computational tools, and nurtured a culturally responsive learning environment. The outcomes of this project serve as a foundation for ongoing improvement and growth, as we continue to strive to remove academic barriers and promote excellence in STEM courses at KBOCC.

 


Last Modified: 05/15/2023
Modified by: Karen M Colbert
